sentence.text: Previous investigations have demonstrated that single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) of NER pathway genes were associated with various types of cancer.
However, there was no research elucidating the genetic association of entire NER pathway with ovarian cancer susceptibility.
Therefore, we conducted genotyping for 17 SNPs of six NER core genes (li>XPA, XPC, XPG, ERCC1, ERCC2, and li>ERCC4) in 89 ovarian cancer cases and 356 cancer-free controls.

The result showed that both li>ERCC1 rs11615 and li>XPC rs2228000 were significantly associated with reduced risk of ovarian cancer under dominant genetic model (adjusted OR = 0.35, 95% CI = 0.20-0.61, li>P=0.0002 and adjusted OR = 0.49, 95% CI = 0.30-0.81, li>P=0.005 respectively).

In addition, li>XPC rs2228001 and li>ERCC2 rs238406 had statistically significant association with the increased risk of ovarian cancer under dominant genetic model (adjusted OR = 1.72, 95% CI = 1.02-2.92, li>P=0.043 and adjusted OR = 2.07, 95% CI = 1.07-4.01, li>P=0.032 respectively).
ERCC1 rs3212986 were related with the increased risk of ovarian cancer under recessive model (adjusted OR = 2.40, 95% CI = 1.30-4.44, li>P=0.005).
In conclusion, our results indicated that li>ERCC1, XPC and li>ERCC2 might influence ovarian cancer susceptibility.
